questions.question: Intellectual property rights include protections for software.
Fair use allows unlimited copying of intellectual property.
Creating the first copy of intellectual property is costly.
Duplicates of intellectual property cost almost nothing.
Illegal copying of intellectual property is not pervasive on the internet.
Open-source software is not protected by intellectual property rights.
Peer-to-peer networks are always used for illegal copying.
Intellectual property refers to any unique product of the human intellect that has commercial value.
Books, songs, and movies are examples of intellectual property.
Paintings and drawings are not considered intellectual property.
Inventions and chemical formulas are examples of intellectual property.
Intellectual property only includes ideas and not their physical manifestations.
People have a right to property in their own person.
People have a right to their own labor.
People have a right to things which they remove from Nature through their labor, such as cutting wood-logs.
If two people write the same play, both can own it.
Every intellectual property is one-of-a-kind.
Copying an intellectual property is the same as stealing a physical object.
Some people are altruistic; some are not.
People cannot benefit from having ownership of their ideas.
Attraction of wealth can be an incentive for work.
Giving creators rights to their inventions discourages creativity.
Society benefits most when inventions are in the public domain.
Congress has not struck a compromise regarding intellectual property protection.
The authors of the U.S. Constitution recognized the benefits of limited intellectual property protection.
Trade secrets are public information that companies share to gain a competitive advantage.
Copyrights provide exclusive rights for novels for a limited period of time.
Trademarks are not considered a form of intellectual property protection.
Patents are a type of intellectual property protection.
Trade secrets can include formulas, customer lists, and strategic plans.
Trade secrets are suitable for all types of intellectual properties, including movies.
Reverse engineering a product like Coca-Cola to figure out its formula is illegal.
Trade secrets may be compromised when employees leave the firm.
A trademark is given by a government to identify a distinctive product.
A trademark can only be represented by a word and not by a symbol or picture.
A service mark identifies products.
A company can establish a brand name.
Trademarks expire after a certain period.
If a brand name becomes a common noun, the trademark may be lost.
Companies advertise to protect their trademarks by using verbs and nouns.
Companies protect trademarks by contacting those who misuse them.
A patent is a secret invention.
A patent provides the owner with exclusive rights to the invention.
The exclusive rights granted by a patent last for 10 years.
After the patent expires, anyone can make use of the idea.
The Polaroid vs Kodak case is an example related to instant photography.
Copyright provides the owner of an original work with three rights.
One of the rights granted by copyright is the right to reproduce the work.
Distribution of copies of the work to the public is not a right granted by copyright.
Public display of copies of the work is one of the rights granted by copyright.
Public performance is an example of copyright protection.
Production of derivative works does not require permission from the copyright holder.
Copyright protection has decreased since 1970.
Fair use allows reproduction of copyrighted works without permission under certain conditions.
Citing short excerpts for news reporting is considered fair use.
Educational use is permissible under fair use, but commercial use is not.
Fiction works are always preferred over nonfiction works under fair use.
Fair use allows copying brief excerpts of a work but not the entire work.
Using out-of-print works is not permissible under fair use.
Copying from vinyl records to cassette tapes introduced distortions in the audio quality.
The introduction of compact discs (CDs) was cheaper to produce than vinyl records.
CDs offer lower quality compared to vinyl records.
Companies charged higher prices for CDs, leading to higher profits.
It is impossible to make a perfect copy of a CD.
Digital Rights Management (DRM) includes encrypting digital content.
Digital marking in DRM prevents devices from recognizing content as copy-protected.
Criticisms of Digital Rights Management (DRM) focus on its technological limitations.
DRM reduces fair use.
DRM could increase competition.
Some schemes make unknown access impossible.
Media Player tracks the contents the users view.
Peer-to-peer networks connect computers running different networking programs.
Computers in a P2P network can access files stored on each other’s hard drives.
P2P networks restrict data exchange between users.
Napster began operation in 1999.
Napster was sued by the RIAA for copyright violations.
The courts ruled in favor of Napster in the lawsuit filed by the RIAA.
Napster is a peer-to-peer music exchange network.
Napster is still operational today.
BitTorrent re-emerged in 2003 as a subscription music service.
BitTorrent speeds up downloading by breaking files into pieces.
In BitTorrent, all pieces of a file are downloaded from a single computer.
BitTorrent is commonly used for downloading large files like movies and TV shows.
Broadband connections typically upload faster than they download.
BitTorrent is a peer-to-peer file transfer protocol.
In 2003, the RIAA sued four students for distributing copyrighted music.
The RIAA settled the lawsuit for $100 billion.
Universities are hotspots for file sharing.
High-speed Internet access is not a factor in file sharing at universities.
The RIAA lawsuit against the students was settled for $50,000.
Banning file-sharing is one of the methods mentioned to address music piracy.
Legal music services like Napster offer free downloads without any fees.
Apple’s iTunes Music Store is mentioned as a leading service for legal music downloads.
Copyright protection for software began in 1964.
The expression of an idea is protected by copyright, not the idea itself.
The implementation of a DBMS is protected by copyright, but the concept of a DBMS is not.
Source code is typically distributed to the public by software companies.
Companies usually deliver executable files (.exe) rather than source code to protect trade secrets.
Copying a program to give or sell to someone else is a violation of software copyright.
Preloading a program onto the hard disk of a computer being sold is not a copyright violation.
Distributing a program without permission is a violation of software copyright.
Reverse engineering is a safe software development practice.
Companies must protect against unconscious copying of programs.
The 'clean room' software development strategy involves only one team.
Team 1 in the 'clean room' strategy writes specifications based on competitors' programs.
Open-source software is a consequence of proprietary software.
Copyright laws were created in an era with difficulties in making copies.
Copyrights currently serve to promote progress effectively.
Copyrights primarily make authors wealthy.
It is wrong to allow someone to 'own' a piece of intellectual property.
Cooperation is more important than copyright.
Open-source software must always be given away for free.
Open-source software allows others to modify the source code.
There are restrictions on how people can use open-source software.
New versions of open-source programs appear less frequently than proprietary software.
Open-source software eliminates tension between developers and users.
Programs belong to entire community.
Shifts focus from manufacturing to service.
Buying Open Source SW with easy installation steps.
Providing great manuals.
Providing support after sales.
BIND gives DNS for entire Internet.
d tools aims to be 100% standards-compliant and is intended to serve as a reference architecture for DNS software.
Apache runs half of Web servers.
Send mail refers to moving e-mail via the internet.
GNU compilers support languages such as C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Java, and Ada.
Zope is a proprietary web application server.
Zope is written in the Python programming language.
Linux is an open-source operating system.
The text discusses the impact of open-source software.
Linux is putting pressure on companies selling proprietary versions of Unix.
Linux is putting pressure on Microsoft and Apple desktops.
The cost for proprietary operating systems is increasing due to Linux.
Without attracting a critical mass of developers, open-source software quality can be poor.
Without an 'owner,' incompatible versions of open-source software may arise.
Independent groups of users make enhancements, leading to many compatible versions.
Open-source software typically has a strong graphical user interface.
Poor mechanisms are a common critique of the open-source software movement.
Companies will spend billions on new programs.
Software licenses typically prevent you from making copies of software to sell or give away.
Software licenses are legal agreements.
The text discusses the morality of breaking the law.
The text discusses whether society should give intellectual property protection to software.
Copying software reduces software purchases.
Copying software leads to more income for software makers.
The open-source movement demonstrates that many people are willing to give their software-writing skills.
The hardware industry wants to hinder the software industry.
All who get free copies of software can afford to buy it.
Ty would be harmed if certain software packages were not released.
The number of software packages released determines the harm to Ty.
The potential uses of software packages are irrelevant to Ty's harm.
